title: Episode 4-1 Highlights | Kim Soo-hyun Falls for His Wife Kim Ji-won All Over Again...♡
synopsis: Hyun-woo can't stop his heart from racing around Hye-in—whether she's wiping something off his face or trying on a rare Hermès vintage dress. He buys her half-price sneakers, justifying it as 'practical,' but his friend sees through him. When Secretary Kim mentions Hye-in spending time with Eun-sung, Hyun-woo insists he's not jealous... while burning the meat he forgot he was grilling.

contents.translation: Wait a moment. What did you get on your face?

grammar.explanation: Passive verb meaning 'to get something on (oneself)'
grammar.example: 뭘 묻히고 다녀 = what did you get on yourself

contents.culture: Hye-in casually wiping something off Hyun-woo's face—an intimate gesture that catches him off guard.

contents.translation: Oh, geez. Aish, ah...

contents.original: 아, 왜 심장이 뛰나 했더니 무서워서 뛴 거야. 어. 엄청 두근두근했다, 진짜.
contents.pronunciation: A, wae simjang-i ttwina haetdeoni museowoseo ttwin geoya. Eo. Eomcheong dugeundugeun-haetda, jinjja.
contents.translation: Oh, I wondered why my heart was racing—it was because I was scared. Yeah. It was really pounding, seriously.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'I wondered if... but then'
grammar.example: 뛰나 했더니 = I wondered why it was racing, and then...

contents.culture: Hyun-woo in denial—convincing himself his racing heart was from fear, not attraction.

contents.translation: Aish...

contents.original: 어때? 오늘 저녁 헤르만 회장 미팅에 입고 갈 건데.
contents.pronunciation: Eottae? Oneul jeonyeok Hermann hoejang miting-e ipgo gal geonde.
contents.translation: How is it? I'm going to wear this to the meeting with Chairman Hermann tonight.

grammar.explanation: Casual 'how is it/what do you think'

grammar.example: 입고 갈 건데 = I'm going to wear it

contents.translation: Yeah.
It's the 1982 Hermès vintage line.

grammar.example: 빈티지 라인이야 = it's the vintage line

contents.culture: Hermès vintage pieces from specific years are extremely rare and valuable in luxury fashion circles.

contents.translation: Really?

contents.original: 전 세계에 딱 두 벌인데 하나는 헤르만 회장 부인이 갖고 있고 다른 하나가 이거.
contents.pronunciation: Jeon segye-e ttak du beor-inde hana-neun Hermann hoejang buin-i gatgo itgo dareun hana-ga igeo.
contents.translation: There are only two in the entire world—one belongs to Chairman Hermann's wife, and the other is this one.

grammar.example: 딱 두 벌 = exactly two pieces
두 벌 = two pieces/sets of clothing

contents.culture: Owning one of only two pieces in the world showcases Hye-in's extreme wealth and fashion connections.

contents.translation: Is it not good?
It's not bad. Well... it's okay.

grammar.example: 별로는 아니야 = it's not that it's bad

contents.culture: Hyun-woo's understated response while clearly being mesmerized.

contents.original: 왜 이뻐? 왜 이쁘지? 아니, 왜?
contents.pronunciation: Wae ippeo? Wae ippeuji? Ani, wae?
contents.translation: Why is she pretty? Why is she so pretty? No, why?

grammar.example: 왜 이뻐 = why is she pretty

contents.culture: Hyun-woo's internal monologue—he can't understand why he's suddenly noticing her beauty.

contents.translation: What are you doing?

grammar.example: 뭐 해? = what are you doing?

contents.translation: Let's go.
Your suit looks good today.

grammar.example: 수트 좋다 = the suit looks good

contents.culture: Hye-in complimenting Hyun-woo—another sign of her warming feelings.

contents.translation: The suit?
Yeah, you look cool.
Good work.

grammar.explanation: Expression meaning 'to work hard/have a hard time'

contents.original: 미간 봐라. 뭐가 마음에 안 드네. 꼭 한번 뒤집어지겠다. 5, 4, 3, 2, 1.
contents.pronunciation: Migan bwara. Mwoga maeum-e an deune. Kkok hanbeon dwijibeojigetda. O, sa, sam, i, il.
contents.translation: Look at that frown. Something's bothering her. She's definitely going to flip out. 5, 4, 3, 2, 1.

grammar.example: 미간 봐라 = look at her frown

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to flip out/get very angry'
grammar.example: 뒤집어지겠다 = she's going to flip out

contents.culture: Employees can read Hye-in's moods by her facial expressions and predict her outbursts.

contents.original: 퍼스널 쇼퍼룸을 하나의 아트 전시관처럼 꾸미겠다며. 작가 인지도도 그렇고 색감도. 우리 PSR 인테리어랑 안 어울리잖아.
contents.pronunciation: Peoseoneol syopeo-rum-eul hana-ui ateu jeonsi-gwan-cheoreom kkumigеtdamyeo. Jakga injido-do geureoko saekgam-do. Uri PSR interiео-rang an eoullijana.
contents.translation: You said you'd decorate the Personal Shopper Room like an art gallery. The artist's recognition and the colors—they don't match our PSR interior.

grammar.example: 전시관처럼 꾸미다 = decorate like a gallery

contents.culture: PSR (Personal Shopper Room) is a VIP service area in luxury department stores for high-end clients.

contents.original: 눈시퍼렇게 뜨고 참 못했다. 못했어. 저러니 내가 무서워서 가슴이 두근거리고 막 떨리고 그러지.
contents.pronunciation: Nunsipeo-reoke tteuko cham motaetda. Motaesseo. Jeoreoni naega museowoseo gaseum-i dugеungeorigo mak tteolligo geureoji.
contents.translation: With her eyes wide open, she really let them have it. She didn't hold back. That's why my heart pounds and I tremble from fear around her.

grammar.example: 눈시퍼렇게 뜨고 = with eyes wide open

contents.culture: Hyun-woo continues his denial—attributing his physical reactions to fear rather than attraction.

contents.translation: Yes, this is it.
What's gotten into you? You're excited?
Not bad.

contents.original: 어이, 왜, 왜 이래? 왜 웃어? 정신 차리자, 진짜.
contents.pronunciation: Eoi, wae, wae irae? Wae useo? Jeongsin charija, jinjja.
contents.translation: Hey, why, what's wrong with me? Why am I smiling? Get a grip, seriously.

grammar.explanation: Idiom meaning 'to get a grip/come to one's senses'
grammar.example: 정신 차리자 = let's get a grip

contents.culture: Hyun-woo catching himself smiling and trying to snap out of it.

contents.original: 야, 너 지금 위험하다. 원래 배우들 좀 봐. 사랑하는 연기하다가 진짜 사랑하게 돼서 결혼하고 그러잖아. 현빈, 손예진을 봐.
contents.pronunciation: Ya, neo jigeum wiheom-hada. Wonrae baeu-deul jom bwa. Sarang-haneun yeongi-hadaga jinjja sarang-hage dwaeseo gyeolhon-hago gеureojana. Hyeonbin, Son Yejin-eul bwa.
contents.translation: Hey, you're in danger right now. Look at actors. They act like they're in love and end up really falling in love and getting married. Look at Hyun Bin and Son Ye-jin.

grammar.example: 사랑하는 연기하다 = to act like you're in love

contents.culture: 현빈 & 손예진 (Hyun Bin & Son Ye-jin) are a real celebrity couple who met while filming 'Crash Landing on You' and later married—a famous case of art imitating life.

contents.translation: It's not like that at all.

grammar.example: 전혀 아니야 = it's not at all

contents.translation: It's not like that at all. You bought her sneakers?

contents.original: 아유, 가만히 있어도 가라고 만든 게 에스컬레이터인데. 뭘 얼마나 빨리 가겠다고. 저래, 진짜. 조심해!
contents.pronunciation: Ayu, gamanhi isseodo garago mandeun ge eseukеolreiteo-inde. Mwol eolmana ppalli gagetdago. Jeorae, jinjja. Josimhae!
contents.translation: Geez, escalators are made so you can go even if you stand still. How fast does she need to go? Seriously. Be careful!

grammar.example: 가만히 있어도 = even if you stay still

contents.culture: Hyun-woo worrying about Hye-in walking on the escalator—protective instincts kicking in.

contents.translation: Didn't someone just yell?

grammar.example: 소리 지르지 않았어? = didn't someone yell?

contents.original: 그러게요. 아니, 어떤 미친놈이 백화점에서 소리를 지르지.
contents.pronunciation: Geureoge-yo. Ani, eotteon michin-nom-i baekhwajeom-eseo sori-reul jireuji.
contents.translation: Right? I mean, what crazy person yells in a department store.
contents.culture: Irony—Hyun-woo was the one who yelled, but he plays it off.

contents.translation: Sir, may I help you?
Yeah. Do you have this in size 240?

grammar.explanation: Korean shoe size (240mm = approx. US women's 7)

contents.culture: Korean shoe sizes are measured in millimeters. 240mm is a common women's size.

contents.translation: So you bought her those sneakers.

contents.original: 야, 그럼 네 말대로 유언장도 아직 안 고쳤는데 뇌진탕으로 가게 둬?
contents.pronunciation: Ya, geureom ne mal-daero yueonjang-do ajik an gochyeonneunde noejintang-euro gage dwo?
contents.translation: Hey, like you said, I haven't even changed the will yet—should I let her get a concussion?

grammar.example: 유언장도 안 고쳤는데 = I haven't changed the will yet

contents.culture: Hyun-woo justifying his protective behavior with his inheritance scheme—still in denial about his real feelings.

contents.translation: Oh, so that's why.

grammar.example: 그래서 그랬구나 = so that's why you did that

contents.original: 당연하지. 나는 놀랐어. 나의 이런 계산적이고 냉철한 면모에.
contents.pronunciation: Dangyeon-haji. Na-neun nollasseo. Na-ui ireon gyesanjeok-igo naengcheolhan myeonmo-e.
contents.translation: Of course. I was surprised at myself—at this calculating, cold-hearted side of me.

grammar.example: 면모에 = at this side of me

contents.translation: So what did she say when you gave it to her?

grammar.example: 주니까 뭐래? = what did she say when you gave it?

contents.translation: Uh... 'You bought it because it was half price?'

grammar.example: 반값이라 = because it was half price

contents.culture: Hye-in's dismissive response to the gift—focusing on the price rather than the gesture.

contents.original: 심지어 오늘이 마지막 날. 게다가 240 사이즈가 인기 사이즈고 화이트 컬러는 전국적으로 품절인데 이거 하나 남았다는 거야. 안 살 수가 없었어.
contents.pronunciation: Simjieo oneuri majimak nal. Gedaga i-baek-sasip saijeu-ga ingi saijeu-go hwaiteu keolleo-neun jeonguk-jеogеuro pumjeor-inde igeo hana namatdaneun geoya. An sal su-ga eopsеosseo.
contents.translation: Plus, today was the last day. Also, 240 is a popular size and white was sold out nationwide, but there was one left. I couldn't not buy it.

grammar.pattern: 안 ~(으)ㄹ 수가 없다 (an eul su-ga eopda)
grammar.example: 안 살 수가 없었어 = I couldn't not buy it

contents.original: 그랬겠네. 그런데 돈을 덜 주고가 아니라 오히려 더 주고 산 신발들로만 슈 클로젯을 꽉 채운 내가. 반값 주고 산 운동화를 신을 일이 있을까?
contents.pronunciation: Geuraetgenne. Geureonde don-eul deol jugo-ga anira ohiryeo deo jugo san sinbal-deul-roman syu keullоjet-eul kkwak chaeun naega. Bangap jugo san undonghwa-reul sineul iri isseulkka?
contents.translation: I guess so. But I filled my shoe closet with shoes I paid more for, not less. Would I ever wear sneakers I bought at half price?

grammar.example: 오히려 더 주고 = rather, paying more

contents.culture: Hye-in's chaebol logic—she's proud of overpaying for luxury items, so discounted sneakers feel beneath her.

contents.original: 당신 비싸고 좋은 신발 많은 거 내가 잘 알지. 그런데 그거 다 불편하잖아.
contents.pronunciation: Dangsin bissago joeun sinbal maneun geo naega jal alji. Geureonde geugo da bulpyeon-hajana.
contents.translation: I know you have lots of expensive, nice shoes. But they're all uncomfortable.
But they're pretty.

contents.original: 이것도 예쁘기는 해. 또 힐이 막 연필심처럼 가늘고 또 이따만하니까 넘어질까 봐 불안하기도 하고.
contents.pronunciation: Igeotdo yeppeugi-neun hae. Tto hil-i mak yeonpilsim-cheoreom ganеulgo tto ittamanhanikka neomeojilkka bwa buran-hagido hago.
contents.translation: This is pretty too. And the heels are thin like pencil lead, and they're this tall so I get anxious about falling.

grammar.example: 연필심처럼 가늘고 = thin like pencil lead

contents.original: 가끔은 그냥 편한 걸 신고 다녀도 될 것 같아서.
contents.pronunciation: Gakkeum-eun geunyang pyeonhan geol singo danyeodo doel geot gataseo.
contents.translation: I thought sometimes I could just wear something comfortable.

grammar.example: 편한 걸 신고 = wearing something comfortable

contents.culture: Hyun-woo's thoughtfulness—he noticed her discomfort and wanted her to have practical options.

contents.translation: Leave it then.

grammar.example: 두고 가던가 = leave it behind then

contents.original: 죽어도 좋은 소리 못 들은 거네.
contents.pronunciation: Jugeodo joeun sori mot deureun geone.
contents.translation: So you couldn't get a single nice word out of her.

grammar.example: 죽어도 못 = can't no matter what
좋은 소리 못 들었다 = couldn't hear nice words

contents.original: 나도 솔직히 혜인이 반응 좀 어이없었어. 그런데 더 어이없는 건 뭔지 아냐?
contents.pronunciation: Na-do solchiki Hyein-i ban-eung jom eoi-eopseosseo. Geureonde deo eoi-eomneun geon mwonji anya?
contents.translation: Honestly, I was a bit taken aback by Hye-in's reaction too. But you know what's even more ridiculous?
What?
She wore them.

grammar.example: 신었더라고 = (I saw that) she wore them

contents.culture: The twist—despite her dismissive words, Hye-in actually wore the sneakers. Actions speak louder than words.

contents.translation: Wow, the boss today is really...
Right? She's pretty today, isn't she?

contents.original: 아니요. 되게 전투적이시라고요. 누가 하나 걸리면 밟아버리겠다는 포스잖아요.
contents.pronunciation: Aniyo. Doege jeontujeok-isiragоyo. Nuga hana geollimyeon balbabeorig etdaneun poseu-janayo.
contents.translation: No. She looks really combative. Like she'll crush anyone who gets in her way.
contents.culture: 포스 (force/aura) is commonly used slang to describe someone's powerful presence or vibe.

contents.translation: Exactly.

contents.original: 그런데 저 두 분은 요새 붙어다니시는데.
contents.pronunciation: Geureonde jeo du bun-eun yosae buteodani-sineunde.
contents.translation: But those two have been sticking together lately.
contents.culture: Secretary Kim noticing Hye-in and Eun-sung spending a lot of time together.

contents.original: 아, 베르키나 입점 때문에 일 얘기가 많아서.
contents.pronunciation: A, Bereukina ipjeom ttaemun-e il yaegi-ga manaseo.
contents.translation: Oh, because of the Verkina store opening, they have a lot of work to discuss.

grammar.example: 입점 때문에 = because of the store opening

contents.original: 윤 대표님이 요새 매일 백화점으로 출근하셔서 밥도 같이 드시고 커피도 같이 산책도 같이 하시는 것 같던데.
contents.pronunciation: Yun daepyo-nim-i yosae maeil baekhwajeom-euro chulgeun-hasyeoseo bap-do gachi deusigo keopi-do gachi sanchaek-do gachi hasineun geot gatdeonde.
contents.translation: CEO Yoon has been coming to the department store every day lately—eating together, having coffee together, taking walks together.

grammar.example: 하시는 것 같던데 = it seemed like they were doing

contents.original: 김 비서가 잘 모르나 본데 원래 워커홀릭들은 밥 먹고 커피 마시는 시간도 아껴서 일 얘기를 하거든. 그래서 그래.
contents.pronunciation: Kim biseo-ga jal moreuna bonde wonrae wokeo-hollik-deul-eun bap meokgo keopi masineun sigan-do akkyeoseo il yaegi-reul hageodeun. Geuraeseo geurae.
contents.translation: Secretary Kim doesn't seem to know, but workaholics save even meal and coffee time to talk about work. That's why.
contents.culture: Hyun-woo desperately rationalizing why Hye-in spends so much time with Eun-sung.

contents.translation: Huh?

contents.original: 아니, 윤 대표가 혜인이 친구라면서 저렇게 아무것도 모르네. 홍혜인 사장은 세상에서 제일 싫어하는 게 누가 자기 머리 만지는 거예요.
contents.pronunciation: Ani, Yun daepyo-ga Hyein-i chingu-ramyeonseo jeoreoke amugeotdo moreune. Hong Hyein sajang-eun sesang-eseo jeil sireohaneun ge nuga jagi meori manjineun geoyeyo.
contents.translation: No, CEO Yoon claims to be Hye-in's friend but doesn't know anything. Boss Hong Hye-in's most hated thing in the world is someone touching her hair.

grammar.example: 친구라면서 = while claiming to be her friend
제일 싫어하는 게 = the thing she hates most

contents.original: 그냥 웃으시는데. 머리 만지는 거 별로 안 싫어하시나 봐요.
contents.pronunciation: Geunyang useusineunde. Meori manjineun geo byeollo an sireоhasinaе bwayo.
contents.translation: She's just smiling. Maybe she doesn't dislike having her hair touched that much.

grammar.example: 안 싫어하시나 봐요 = it seems she doesn't dislike it

contents.culture: The observation that bothers Hyun-woo—Hye-in lets Eun-sung touch her hair but supposedly hates it.

contents.original: 그래서 지금 그거 막 신경 쓰이는 거야, 질투 나고?
contents.pronunciation: Geuraeseo jigeum geugo mak singyeong sseuineun geoya, jiltu nago?
contents.translation: So that's bothering you now? Are you jealous?

grammar.example: 신경 쓰이는 거야 = it's bothering you

contents.original: 너 나 말할 때 어디 갔다 왔니? 내 말의 포인트를 모르겠어? 네 말의 포인트가 그거잖아. 나 질투 난다.
contents.pronunciation: Neo na malhal ttae eodi gatda wanni? Nae mar-ui pointeu-reul moreugesseo? Ne mar-ui pointeu-ga geugeojana. Na jiltu nanda.
contents.translation: Where did you go when I was talking? Don't you get my point? Your point is exactly that—'I'm jealous.'

grammar.example: 포인트를 모르겠어 = don't you get the point

contents.original: 너 질투가 뭔지 몰라? 그거는 내가 누군가를 좋아하고 있는데 경쟁자나 방해꾼이 나타났을 때 느끼는 거지.
contents.pronunciation: Neo jiltu-ga mwonji molla? Geugeoneun naega nugungа-reul joahago inneunde gyeongjaeng-ja-na banghaek-kun-i natanasseul ttae neukkineun geoji.
contents.translation: Don't you know what jealousy is? It's what you feel when you like someone and a rival or obstacle appears.

grammar.example: 방해꾼이 나타났을 때 = when an obstacle appears

contents.original: 전제가 틀렸잖아. 내가 홍혜인을 좋아하지는 않는데 왜 질투를 하겠냐고.
contents.pronunciation: Jeonje-ga teullyeotjana. Naega Hong Hyein-eul joahaji-neun anneunde wae jiltu-reul hagetnyago.
contents.translation: The premise is wrong. I don't like Hong Hye-in, so why would I be jealous?

grammar.example: 전제가 틀렸잖아 = the premise is wrong
왜 질투를 하겠냐고 = why would I be jealous

contents.translation: I'm saying I'm fine.

grammar.example: 아무렇지 않다고 = I'm saying I'm fine

contents.original: 어, 전혀. 뭐 나는 뭐 상관없지. 둘이 친하든 말든 둘이 같이 어딜 가든 말든.
contents.pronunciation: Eo, jeonhyeo. Mwo na-neun mwo sanggwan-eopji. Dul-i chinhadeun maldeun dul-i gachi eodil gadeun maldeun.
contents.translation: Yeah, not at all. I don't care. Whether they're close or not, whether they go somewhere together or not.

grammar.example: 친하든 말든 = whether close or not

contents.culture: Classic denial—the more Hyun-woo insists he doesn't care, the more obvious it is that he does.

contents.original: 알겠어. 그런데 너 아까부터 고기 안 굽고 뭘 굽고 있냐?
contents.pronunciation: Algesseo. Geureonde neo akkabuteo gogi an gupgo mwol gupgo innya?
contents.translation: Okay. But what have you been grilling instead of meat this whole time?

grammar.example: 뭘 굽고 있냐 = what are you grilling

contents.culture: The punchline—Hyun-woo was so distracted thinking about Hye-in and Eun-sung that he burned the meat at the Korean BBQ.
